questions.text: Are you married, never married, divorced, separated, or widowed?
questions.label: Marital Status
questions.tip_text: There is a documented relationship between marital status and outcome of coronary artery disease. If you are married, consider involving your spouse in your health-care program in order to increase the odds of making the appropriate lifestyle changes nece

questions.text: Who are the other members of your household?
questions.label: Household Members
questions.tip_text: People who have a stable and supportive living environment tend to have a better outcome in the presence of heart disease. Multiple studies have reported that a happy home life is associated with reduced risk of heart disease.

questions.text: Do you practice any religion?  If so,  which one?
questions.label: Religion
questions.tip_text: Religious preferences are helpful in developing appropriate dietary recommendations.

questions.text: What is your highest educational degree/level?
questions.label: Education
questions.tip_text: There is a documented relationship between the level of education and the incidence and outcomes of heart disease.

questions.text: What is the highest job level in your household, held either by you or any another member of your household?
questions.label: Household Job Level
questions.tip_text: High job level(s) in the household and associated stress levels may be associated with heart disease.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes your current occupation?
questions.label: Current Occupation
questions.tip_text: Being employed is associated with improved longevity and health

answer_options.description: Unable to work due to injury or disability

questions.text: Describe what you do during a typical day.
questions.label: Typical Day Description

questions.text: What is your job title?
questions.label: Job Title

questions.text: How many hours a week do you work?
questions.label: Hours of Work per Week
questions.tip_text: Long work hours may reduce your available time for exercise and relaxation.

questions.text: How long does it take you to drive to work?
questions.label: Commute Time
questions.tip_text: Long commute patterns may reduce your available time for exercise and relaxation.

answer_options.description: Walk, bike or take public transport

questions.text: How many days do you spend in transit for work based travel each year?
questions.label: Time Travelling for Work

questions.text: Have you ever been diagnosed with:
questions.label: Diagnosed Conditions

answer_options.description: CAD (Coronary Artery Disease)/ Heart Attack/ Angina/ Blockage/ Calcification/ Ischemic Stress Test

Stroke / Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) - A transient ischemic attack or TIA, often referred to as a 'mini stroke' is caused by the changes in the blood supply to a particular area of the brain, resulting in brief neurologic dysfunction that persists for

Peripheral Vascular/Arterial Disease (PVD or PAD) - Peripheral Vascular/Arterial  Disease refers to blockages that can occur in the arteries that carry blood to the arms and legs.  It is the obstruction of large arteries not within the coronary, aortic ar

Cerebrovascular or Carotid Artery Disease - Cerebrovascular Disease is a disease affecting any artery supplying blood to the brain; may cause blockage or rupture of a blood vessel, leading to a stroke.  Carotid Artery Disease is a progressive disease that
Congestive Heart Failure - A condition in which the heart fails to pump an adequate supply of blood to the body tissues, often resulting in fluid accumulation in the lungs and/or lower extremities.

questions.text: What actions are you currently taking to control your diagnosed condition(s)?
questions.label: Medical Condition Actions
questions.tip_text: Lifestyle changes you might have made in order to control your condition may include changes to your normal diet, changes to your exercise regimen, or changing your exposure to stress.

questions.text: What were the results of your most recent stress test, if any?
questions.label: Had a Stress Test

answer_options.description: I've never had a stress test
I don't remember having a stress test
I've had a stress test but don't know the results
My stress test result was normal (did NOT indicate blockage)
My stress test was abnormal (indicated blockage)

questions.text: What was the year of and the reason for the stress test?
questions.label: E.g. Routine, chest pain, other.
questions.tip_text: Understanding why your doctor felt it was necessary to conduct the test, including the symptoms that led to the evaluation can help with heart health recommendations.

questions.text: What, if any, heart related event or procedure(s) have you had?
questions.label: Heart Event Diary

questions.text: Please describe your medical history.
questions.label: Personal History Description

questions.text: What medications do you take on a regular basis?
questions.label: Medication Diary

questions.text: Do you take your prescribed medication regularly?
questions.label: Medication Compliance

questions.text: Do you have any allergies or reactions to medication?
questions.label: Allergy to Medication

questions.text: Describe your allergies/reactions and indicate which medication(s) trigger them:
questions.label: Med Allergy Description
questions.tip_text: This question is to ensure participant safety.

questions.text: Have you experienced menopause?
questions.label: Menopause
questions.tip_text: The onset of menopause increases the risk for heart disease.

questions.text: Has a biological parent, sibling or child ever been diagnosed with:
questions.label: Diagnosed Family Conditions

answer_options.description: Early heart disease - before 55 men or 65 women (i.e. Coronary Artery Disease/ Heart Attack/ Angina/ Blockage/ Calcification/ Angioplasty/ Stent/ Procedure/ Bypass)

Stroke/ Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) - A transient ischemic attack or TIA, often referred to as a 'mini stroke' is caused by the changes in the blood supply to a particular area of the brain, resulting in brief neurologic dysfunction that persists for

Peripheral Vascular/Arterial Disease (PVD or PAD) - Peripheral Vascular/Arterial  Disease refers to blockages that can occur in the arteries that carry blood to the arms and legs.  It is the obstruction of large arteries not within the coronary, aortic ar

Cerebrovascular or Carotid Artery Disease - Cerebrovascular Disease is a disease affecting any artery supplying blood to the brain; may cause blockage or rupture of a blood vessel, leading to a stroke.  Carotid Artery Disease is a progressive disease that
Congestive Heart Failure - A condition in which the heart fails to pump an adequate supply of blood to the body tissues, often resulting in fluid accumulation in the lungs and/or lower extremities.
None, no one in my family has suffered from any of these

questions.text: Please describe your family's medical history.
questions.label: Family History Description

questions.text: Do you currently or have ever smoked on a regular basis?
questions.label: Smoker
questions.tip_text: Use of tobacco products such as cigarettes, cigars, pipes, hookah, beetle leaves (paan) with tobacco or nicorette gum, is a significant risk factor for heart disease and heart attacks. The discontinuation of tobacco products is accompanied by a rapid and

questions.text: How many cigarettes do/did you smoke in a typical day?
questions.label: There are approximately 20 cigarettes in a pack
questions.tip_text: Cigarettes per day

answer_options.description: 20+, a pack or more a day

questions.text: At what age did you start smoking cigarettes?
questions.label: Age Started Smoking

questions.text: At what age did you quit smoking cigarettes?
questions.label: Age Quit Smoking

questions.text: Would you like help trying to quit smoking?
questions.label: Would Like Help to Quit Smoking
questions.tip_text: Research has shown that within six months of quitting smoking, your risk for heart disease falls by 50%.

questions.text: Are you currently under stress?
questions.label: Stress Level
questions.tip_text: Stress is associated with increased risk of high blood pressure, obesity, diabetes, and heart disease.

questions.text: How content are you currently?
questions.label: Contentment Level

questions.text: Do you engage in any stress reduction activities such as yoga, stretching with the purpose of relaxation, etc.?
questions.label: Relaxation Activity
questions.tip_text: Personal autonomy can reduce the risk of heart disease.

questions.text: How many times a week do you engage in this stress reduction activity?
questions.label: Frequency of Relaxation Activity

questions.text: Do you practice meditation?
questions.label: Meditation
questions.tip_text: Samadhi is a profound state of restful alertness associated with decreased heart disease, insulin resistance, and high blood-pressure. Transcendental meditation is an easy technique to bring about this state.

questions.text: What type of meditation do you practice?
questions.label: Meditation Type
questions.tip_text: Certain types of meditation techniques have been studied extensively and their health benefit has been scientifically documented. Transcendental Meditation has been the focus of numerous such studies.

questions.text: Please describe the type of meditation you practice.
questions.label: Meditation Description

questions.text: How many times per week do you practice meditation?
questions.label: Meditation Frequency
questions.tip_text: times per week

questions.text: How many minutes per day do you practice meditation?
questions.label: Meditation Minutes
questions.tip_text: minutes

questions.text: Are you currently (in the last month) physically active?
questions.label: Regularity of Physical Activity
questions.tip_text: Individuals are physically active if they are regularly involved in moderate or strenuous exercise for at least 150 minutes or more a week.

questions.text: For what amount of time are you physically active during the day?
questions.label: Physical Activity Minutes
questions.tip_text: minutes

questions.text: List/describe the physical activities that you do regularly.
questions.label: Physical Activity Detail

questions.text: How often do you perform these physical activities to your maximal level of effort?
questions.label: Maximal Effort during Physical Activity
questions.tip_text: Amount of exercise is more important than intensity of exercise, but intensity remains important. The intensity of exercise achievable or recommended is dependent on your body type, age and personal medical history.

questions.text: How long do you just sit without a break, on a regular basis?
questions.label: Time Spent Just Sitting

answer_options.description: I do not just sit for extended period of time
I do sit, but for fewer than 3 hours without a break
I do sit, and for 3 hours or longer without a break

questions.text: Are you vegetarian?
questions.label: Vegetarian
questions.tip_text: There is a popular belief that being vegetarian is cardio protective among South Asians. However, not all vegetarian diets are the same. Diet plays an important role in the prevention as well as development of heart disease.

answer_options.description: No, I eat meat and/or fish

questions.text: How many servings of vegetables do you eat on an average each day?
questions.label: Vegetables per day
questions.tip_text: Research indicates that 5-9 daily servings of fruits and vegetables significantly decreases cardiac and cancer related morbidity and mortality.

questions.text: How many of your vegetable servings come from yellow/orange or dark green/leafy vegetables?
questions.label: Colored Vegetables per day
questions.tip_text: Research indicates that vegetables that grow on vines such as squashes, beans, okra, and greens such as spinach, collards, swiss chard, purslane have significant effects on longevity and cardiac health. These effects have not been found to be associated w

questions.text: How many servings of fruit do you eat on an average each day?
questions.label: Fruit per day
questions.tip_text: Research indicates that 5-9 daily servings of fruits and vegetables significantly decreases cardiac and cancer related morbidity and mortality.

questions.text: On average, how many total servings of grain products do you eat each day?
questions.label: Grain Servings per day

questions.text: Of the servings of grain above, how many are servings of whole grain products?
questions.label: Whole Grain Servings per day
questions.tip_text: Whole grain products increase dietary fiber and have been shown to decrease risk of heart disease, diabetes and cancer. Whole grain products include whole wheat, whole rye, oats, oatmeal, bulgur, cracked wheat, popcorn, barley, and brown rice.

questions.text: On average, how many servings of white bread (not whole wheat) do you eat each week?
questions.label: White Bread Servings per week
questions.tip_text: White bread has been associated with the development of diabetes. It should be limited or avoided. This includes sourdough, french bread, croissants, or any bread made with all-purpose flour. Enriched bread is white bread with vitamins added, and is not n

questions.text: Does your daily diet contain more vegetables or more grain?
questions.label: Vegetable or Grain Based Diet

answer_options.description: Equal servings of vegetables and grains

questions.text: Do you consume fish, or take fish-oil/omega-3 oil supplements on a regular basis?
questions.label: Fish or Omega 3 Oils
questions.tip_text: Research shows strong evidence that the omega-3s EPA�and DHA can boost heart health and lower triglycerides. Flaxseed is the source of only one of the 3 essential omega-3 and has been shown to provide no particular CV benefit. Therefore not to be recorded

questions.text: Do you consume nuts on a daily basis?
questions.label: Nut Consumption

answer_options.description: I do not consume nuts on a regular/daily basis

questions.text: How many servings of foods that are high in saturated fat or trans-fats do you eat on an average each week?
questions.label: Sat/Trans Fat Servings per week

questions.text: How many servings of high calorie sweet foods do you eat on an average each week?
questions.label: Sweet Food Servings per week
questions.tip_text: Sweet foods usually have both high carbohydrate content (cakes, donuts, chocolate, Indian sweets) as well as high saturated fat content (indian sweets, ice-cream).

questions.text: How many servings of fruit juice or sweetened drinks do you drink on an average each week?
questions.label: Juice/Sweet Drinks per week
questions.tip_text: Fruit and vegetable juice are a concentrated form of sugar with the highest glycemic index and should be avoided.  Have whole fruits or vegetables instead.  Other common sugar sweetened beverages include sodas, sports drinksand sugar sweetened coffee and

questions.text: How often do you eat (meals or snacks) due to reasons other than hunger?
questions.label: Non-hunger Snacking
questions.tip_text: Eating for entertainment, stress, or boredom can lead to unhealthy weight gain.

questions.text: How many days a week do you eat breakfast?
questions.label: Breakfasts per week
questions.tip_text: Daily breakfast is associated with lower BMI (body mass index) and better health.

questions.text: Describe your specific current diet - South Asian, American, Mixed.
questions.label: Diet Detail/Food Allergies
questions.tip_text: Knowing current dietary habits and restrictions helps in recommending appropriate nutritional modifications to improve heart health.

questions.text: Do you currently consume or have you ever consumed alcohol or alcoholic beverages on a regular basis?
questions.label: Alcohol Consumption
questions.tip_text: Limited amount of alcohol consumption is associated with decreased risk of heart disease. However, alcohol may be addictive, and cause other health problems.

answer_options.description: Rarely consume alcohol (3 times a month or less)
Sometimes consume alcohol (more than 3 times a month but not daily)
Consume alcohol but no information on frequency (pre 3.0)

questions.text: When you drink alcohol, how many drinks do you have at one time?
questions.label: Alcohol Drinks at One Time

questions.text: At what age did you start consuming alcohol?
questions.label: Age Started Drinking Alcohol

questions.text: On an average, how many hours do you sleep each night?
questions.label: Average Sleep
